bestBHT.bht: The Jewish leaders reacted with envy and indignation when they saw the multitudes gathering to hear Paul and Barnabas proclaim Jesus' message. Fueled by their exclusive zeal for Judaism, they interrupted and openly opposed the apostles, denying them the privilege to proceed further. In their jealousy, they indulged in unkind personalities and blasphemed Jesus and his teachings, refusing to accept the application of Messianic prophecies. This episode reminds us of the fierce opposition that arises when the light of the gospel challenges established traditions and hearts.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: There is nothing more awful than Jewish fury and execration of the name of Jesus of Nazareth, when thoroughly roused.
But when the Jews...saw the multitudes, they were filled with envy...and broke out in their usual manner.
Albert Barnes: The word here denotes 'wrath in indignation,' that such multitudes should be disposed to hear a message which they rejected, and which threatened to overthrow their religion.
To speak thus of him is denominated blasphemy.

Precious and pure doctrines are often thus vilified fled because we do not believe them; and the heart of the Saviour is pierced anew, and his cause bleeds, by the wrath and wickedness of his professed friends.
Marvin Vincent: Envy [ζηλου] . Rev., jealousy. See on James 3:14.
John Calvin: They were filled. It is no new matter for the rage of the wicked to be inflamed when the light of the gospel is set somewhat nearer."
And it is to be doubted whether Luke do mean, by the word zeal, that they were moved with a certain wicked indignation, to set themselves against Paul and Barnabas."

And Satan doth for the most part drive the wicked unto such madness, that when they be overcome with reasons and discouraged, they wax harder and harder; and wittingly and willingly they spew out at length blasphemies against God and the truth.
Philip Schaff: It is the Jews only, not the proselytes, who were enraged at the sight of the crowds who flocked to hear the stranger missionaries.
The old exclusive pride of the race of Abraham was stirred up at the thought of these masses of idolaters sharing with the chosen people in all the promised glories of Messiah’s kingdom.

Denying the application of the various Messianic prophecies quoted by the apostles, and most probably accusing and denying that Holy One whose Cross and Resurrection formed the central point of the stranger missionaries’ preaching.
Archibald T. Robertson: Envy and jealousy arise between people of the same calling... So these rabbis boiled with jealousy when they saw the crowds gathered to hear Paul and Barnabas."
It was interruption of the service and open opposition in the public meeting. Paul and Barnabas were guests by courtesy and, of course, could not proceed further, when denied that privilege."
Doubtless these rabbis indulged in unkind personalities and made it plain that Paul and Barnabas were going beyond the limitations of pure Judaism in their contacts with Gentiles.
John Gill: They were filled with envy; at the Gentiles, that they should have the word equally preached to them, as to themselves.
They went on contradicting and blaspheming; publicly opposing him, and speaking evil of him, and of his doctrines.
When you see generation after generation reproaching and blaspheming, look for the feet of the Messiah.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this passage, we witness the Jewish leaders filled with envy and indignation as they saw the multitudes gathering to hear Paul and Barnabas proclaim the message of Jesus. Their exclusive zeal for Judaism led them to interrupt the service and openly oppose the apostles in their contacts with the Gentiles. Filled with jealousy, they indulged in unkind personalities and denied Paul and Barnabas the privilege to proceed further. Their rage and blasphemy against Jesus and his teachings reflect their refusal to accept the application of Messianic prophecies. This passage reminds us of the deep-rooted opposition that can arise when the light of the gospel threatens established traditions and challenges hearts.

The Jewish leaders in Acts 13:45 were filled with envy and indignation when they saw the multitudes flocking to hear Paul and Barnabas share the message of Jesus. Their exclusive zeal for Judaism led them to interrupt and openly oppose the apostles, denying them the privilege to proceed further. Fueled by jealousy, they indulged in unkind personalities and blasphemed against Jesus and his teachings. This incident serves as a reminder of the deep-rooted opposition that can emerge when the light of the gospel challenges established traditions and threatens hearts.

The Jewish leaders in this passage were filled with envy and indignation as they witnessed the multitudes gathering to hear Paul and Barnabas share the message of Jesus. Their exclusive zeal for Judaism led them to interrupt and openly oppose the apostles, denying them the privilege to proceed further. Fueled by jealousy, they indulged in unkind personalities and blasphemed against Jesus and his teachings, reflecting their refusal to accept the application of Messianic prophecies. This account highlights the opposition and blasphemy that can arise when the gospel challenges established traditions.

Fueled by their exclusive zeal for Judaism, they interrupted and openly opposed the apostles, denying them the privilege to proceed further. In their jealousy, they indulged in unkind personalities and blasphemed Jesus and his teachings, refusing to accept the application of Messianic prophecies. This episode reminds us of the fierce opposition that arises when the light of the gospel challenges established traditions and hearts.

The Jewish leaders in Acts 13:45 were filled with envy and indignation at the sight of the multitudes gathering to hear Paul and Barnabas proclaim Jesus' message. Fueled by their exclusive zeal for Judaism, they interrupted and openly opposed the apostles, denying them the privilege to proceed further. Their jealousy led them to indulge in unkind personalities and blaspheme against Jesus and his teachings. This passage reveals the deep-rooted opposition that can arise when the light of the gospel challenges established traditions and threatens hearts.
